items.title: Syrian Refugees Strain Resources in Jordan
items.abstract: Despite plans by aid organizations to help at least 50,000 urban refugees, a large number will be left out because of the rising numbers of Syrians fleeing across the border each day.
keywords: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )

items.title: City Suspends License of Operator in Queens Crane Collapse
items.abstract: The city said the operator had been trying to lift a load more than twice the crane’s capacity at a construction site in Long Island City.

items.title: Egyptians in Port City Reject President’s Effort to Mollify Them
items.abstract: Demonstrators shut down a major port at the Mediterranean entrance to the Suez Canal, ignoring President Mohamed Morsi’s promises of economic development.
keywords: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )

items.title: 36 Hours in Panama City Beach, Fla.
items.abstract: Peer beyond the tattoo parlors and sweaty spring breakers and you’ll find everything from sugary sands to a farmers’ market in this Emerald Coast town.

items.title: Daylight Time Does Begin on Sunday, Despite the Local Law
items.abstract: New Yorkers who know the city’s administrative code may be under the impression that daylight saving time begins in April.

items.title: Taliban Step Up Urban Assaults, Testing the Mettle of Afghan Forces
items.abstract: The government is trying to reassure citizens while the Taliban appears to be trying to strengthen its hand before peace talks.

items.title: New York City Rejects Federal Findings That Many Elementary Schools Defy Disabilities Law
items.abstract: The de Blasio administration took issue with a report saying that the majority of city elementary schools are not fully accessible to disabled people.

items.title: In Tokyo, Brand-Name Stores by Brand-Name Architects
items.abstract: Star architects have created so many high-end stores in Tokyo that it’s worth visiting two shopping districts where the best item — eye-popping building design — is free.

items.title: Audit Faults New York City for Not Using Vacant Lots for Affordable Housing
items.abstract: Comptroller Scott M. Stringer said the city had been slow to develop over 1,000 long-unused properties despite a housing shortage. Housing officials said his conclusions were “false and misleading.”

items.title: Industrially Inspired Condominium in Long Island City
items.abstract: The Jackson, a 56-unit condominium under construction in Queens, looks almost as though it was originally designed to serve a commercial purpose.

items.title: Traffic Deaths in New York City Drop to 200, a Record Low
items.abstract: Fewer people were killed last year in vehicle crashes, a sign that Mayor Bill de Blasio’s Vision Zero plan is working. But pedestrian deaths increased.

items.title: What if Cities Are No Longer the Land of Opportunity for Low-Skilled Workers?
items.abstract: Dense cities have long promised higher wages, but now that is primarily true for workers with more education, a new analysis finds.

items.title: Are Electric Cars Only for the Rich? Sacramento Is Challenging That Notion
items.abstract: With funding from a surprising source, Volkswagen, California is making sure low-income communities have the chance to gain access to electric vehicles.

items.title: Jazmine Headley, Whose Child Was Torn From Her Arms at a City Office, Gets a Public Apology
items.abstract: The mother whose chaotic arrest was captured on video as security officers attempted to extract her son from her arms tearfully spoke to to the City Council today.

items.title: What Democrats Need to Know to Win in Rural America
items.abstract: The G.O.P. under President Trump has given liberals an opening in places like Iowa. But they need to know how to speak to voters here.

items.title: How to Design a Home Gym That You’ll Actually Use
items.abstract: As the pandemic rages on, the safest place to work out is at home. Here’s how to create a personal gym you’ll want to spend time in.

items.title: They Had Reasons for Leaving the City. So Why Are Their Friends Mad?
items.abstract: When Covid hit, some New Yorkers abandoned the city for good. They left some angry friends.

items.title: In a Reversal, Kansas City’s Defense Plays Hero to Beat Broncos
items.abstract: Angling for the top seed in the A.F.C. with a win, Kansas City’s much maligned defense forced a fumble and returned it for a third-quarter touchdown.

items.title: When Production Design Plays a Supporting Role
items.abstract: The visual environments of “West Side Story,” “The Humans” and “Nightmare Alley” feel as alive as the actors.

items.title: How a Boy in Rural Iceland Became a Tool for Global Fascism
items.abstract: “Red Milk,” a novel by Sjón, examines a young man’s path to neo-Nazism.
